title: What is Chelsea Doing?
text: The English Premier League has existed in its current form since 1992, but never before has the world seen anything akin to Chelsea during the 2022/23 season. With Todd Boehly taking charge, the club had money to throw around, spending over 500,000,000 euros over the course of the season. However, Chelsea fell from 3rd in the league in the 2021/22 season to 12th in 2022/2023, with a loss of 29 points. It’s clear by Chelsea’s finish that spending money doesn’t simply get you success. So the question is: what is the optimal amount of money to spend?

title: The Model
text:
Let’s start by asking this question. Let’s say Chelsea’s spending of 500 million euros didn’t devolve into one of the Premier League’s all-time collapses. How should it have worked out for the Blues?





To create this graph, I used the rstanarm package which allowed me to create a fit using stan_glm, which gave information on the relationship between a club’s transfer balance and the points they gained or lost. Using that fit, I told the model that the club had in theory spent 500 million euros and asked it to predict the points they would gain or lose.
Based on the last season, the model dictates that the team would lose around 10-20 points from the previous year. I was skeptical though, due to Chelsea’s season being very weird for a normal team. So I removed Chelsea from the dataset we gave the model and asked to recalculate.





After removing Chelsea from consideration, it becomes more evident that based on the last season, spending big doesn’t lead to big results. The model says while Chelsea’s season was unlikely, it wasn’t improbable. The team should have points, but probably not as many as they did.
What does that say about how to manage a football team? It says you shouldn’t try to spend big to build a better team. Instead, focus on selling off the players you don’t need and bringing in more talent to support your talents. Oddly enough, this is what Chelsea is doing now.
